description.narrative: Plan International Nederland and Stichting World Vision Nederland joined forces under the Sudan Joint Response to provide multi-sectoral assistance to respond to the immediate needs and protection risks of the most vulnerable and conflict affected people in targeted areas in North- Darfur and South Kordofan, through an effective and efficient humanitarian response by Dutch NGOs, local partners and actors.

Refugees, host, IDP and returnee populations affected by the protracted crisis in North-Darfur and South Kordofan, Sudan, with focus on the most vulnerable and conflict affected within the targeted areas (including women, children, women- & child-headed households, elderly and people with disabilities)

SUMMARY In response to the humanitarian situation in Sudan, Plan International takes part in the Sudan Joint Response 2019, in collaboration with the Dutch Relief Alliance funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Plan International Nederland and World Vision Nederland joined forces to provide multi-sectoral assistance to respond to the immediate needs and protection risks of the most vulnerable and conflict affected people in targeted areas in North- Darfur and South Kordofan, through an effective and efficient humanitarian response throughout 2019 (Jan - Dec).
A total of 120.969 direct beneficiaries across the states of North Darfur and South Kordofan benefit from activities providing multi-sectoral assistance in protection, Food Security & livelihoods and WASH (Water, sanitation and Hygiene) sectors. The project targets the most vulnerable and conflict affected people including (refugees, host, IDP) women, children, women- & child-headed households, elderly and people with disabilities.

The humanitarian situation in Sudan remains serious and complex, with acute humanitarian needs across the Darfur region, North Kassala, Blue Nile and South Kordofan states. The Sudan 2018 Humanitarian Needs Overview points to 5.5 million people in need of humanitarian assistance, including 3 million in Darfur and just under 1 million in Kordofan. In response to the humanitarian situation in Sudan,
Considering the existing needs and gaps, as well as organizations’ expertise and capacities, the program will be implemented in the FSL, WASH and Protection sectors. With no SDN JR 2019 partner implementing activities independently, and all programs designed in order to deliver holistic, multi-sectoral and high-impact programs to beneficiaries by multiple partners, the SDN JR 2019 program has, in its very essence, a high collaborative value and impact.

sector.narrative: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation

policy-marker.narrative: Protection and Assistance in Emergencies (Disaster Risk Management)

title.narrative: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

comment.narrative:
Training of 20 WASH committees on PHAST approach (girls;62, Boys;58, women;65, men;55)
Conducting 40 sanitation and hygiene promotion awareness sessions (girls;2600, Boys;2400, women;2700, men;2300)

Due to delay in issuing the 'beschikking' and the political unrest between April and June, this programme activity was temporarily suspended. The SDNJR (with approval from MFA) has also responded to an acute cholera crisis through which 56745 people were supported with hygiene promotion (girls; 14901, Boys; 13759 women; 17781, men; 10304).

title.narrative: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

comment.narrative: The SDNJR (with approval from MFA) has also responded to an acute cholera crisis in White Nile State through which 9840 HH in 50 targeted villages (59044 individual) have received Cholera prevention kits (10 pieces 250 gr Soap, 2 sachets of ORS and 15 purification sachets (chlorine 0.33g) to treat up 40 liters of water for drinking per day) for One month. This in addition to the 800 targeted people for this indicator.

The SDNJR (with approval from MFA) has also responded to an acute cholera crisis through which 9840 HH in 50 targeted villages (59044 individual) have received Cholera prevention kits (10 pieces 250 gr Soap, 2 sachets of ORS and 15 purification sachets (chlorine 0.33g) to treat up 40 liters of water for drinking per day) for One month.

The SDNJR (with approval from MFA) has also responded to an acute cholera crisis through which 9840 HH in 50 targeted villages (59044 individual) have received Cholera prevention kits (10 pieces 250 gr Soap, 2 sachets of ORS and 15 purification sachets (chlorine 0.33g) to treat up 40 liters of water for drinking per day) for One month.

title.narrative: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

comment.narrative:
Construction of permanent school latrines (6 dropholes in 3 schools + handwashing facilities) (girls;242, Boys;242, women;0, men;0)
Construction of 200 household latrine by using CATS approach (girls;312, Boys;288, women;324, men;276)

The SDNJR (with approval from MFA) has also responded to an acute cholera crisis through which 2 permanent VIP latrines has been constructed, one at Saleema primary school, second latrine at Karmal health facility benefited (girls; 557, Boys; 483, women; 319, men; 272).
